qas.question: Antagonistic or antipathetic symbiosis are alternate names for what?
What is it called when organisms are lethal to their host?
What is it called when parasites need their host to live?
What proportion of animals go through a parasitic stage?

plausible_answers.text: biotrophic relationship would be a tick feeding on the blood of its host

qas.question: What is the relationship termed if both organisms benefit?
What relationship happens after a biotrophic relationship occurs from a tick feeding on the blood of its host?
When both organisms benefit in an antipathetic symbiosis it is known as a?
What is an extremely unsuccessful mode of life?
How many fungi have at least one parasitic phase in their life cycles?

context: <a0_0>A <b7_0>parasitic relationship<b7_0/><a0_0/> is one in which one member of the association benefits while the other is harmed. This is also known as antagonistic or antipathetic symbiosis. Parasitic symbioses take many forms, from endoparasites that live within the host's body to ectoparasites that live on its surface. In addition, parasites may be <a1_0><b6_0>necrotrophic<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which is to say they kill their host, or <a2_0>biotrophic<a2_0/>, meaning they rely on their host's surviving. <b8_0>Biotrophic parasitism<b8_0/> is an extremely successful mode of life. Depending on the definition used, <a3_0><b9_0>as many as half<b9_0/><a3_0/> of all animals have at least one parasitic phase in their life cycles, and it is also frequent in plants and fungi. Moreover, almost all free-living animals are host to one or more parasite taxa. An example of a <b5_0>biotrophic relationship would be <a4_0>a tick<a4_0/> feeding on the blood of its host<b5_0/>.
